New Records: New Zealand ended the first innings at Wellington on a total of 215/3, their second highest score at this venue
Key Match Events: Travis Head (24) and David Warner (32) did gave a good start for Australia
Mitchell Marsh (72*) remained on the crease and built small partnership with Glenn Maxwell (25) and Josh Inglis (20)
Tim David (31*) stood till the last with him and led the Australian team to defeat New Zealand by 6 wickets
Devon Conway and Finn Allen provided a stellar start to the Kiwi until Allen was dismissed on a score of 36
Conway then stitched together an over 100 run partnership with Rachin Ravindra, placing the Kiwis over the 150 run mark
The final touch to the innings was put by Mark Chapman and Glenn Phillips who helped the Kiwis go past the 200 run mark
Pre-Game Insights: The Aussies are also in have been in red-hot form after defeating the West Indies 2-1 for the recently concluded T20 series and will be aiming to replicate this form against their neighbours
New Zealand, on the other hand, won their last T20I series against Pakistan with a 4-1 margin and will be aiming to dominate their opponents in last T20 matches before the World Cup
The presence of these big names from both sides means that the first T20 between New Zealand and Australia is likely to be a high-scoring affair
The Sky Stadium pitch, while offering something for the bowlers, is likely to be more in favour of the batsmen, meaning a big score would be the likely outcome
Post-Match Reflections: Australian skipper Mitchell Marsh was announced as the 'Player of the Match' for his 72 unbeaten runs and one wicket taken in the first innings
For the Kiwis, Mitchell Santner picked two wickets, while Lockie Ferguson and Adam Milne took one each
Earlier in the day, Mitchell Santner won the toss and decided to bat first at the Sky Stadium in Wellington
Miscellaneous Highlights: The two teams are set to play 3 T20 encounters, the last for both of them before the start of the T20 World Cup later this year
David Warner is playing his final bilateral series for Australia
The first will be played today at the Sky stadium in Wellington while the second 2nd T20I encounter will be played at Eden Park in Auckland and the third match will also be played at the same venue
